Inside the clinic was as lovely as outside. Smooth, white walls curved gently around them, opening into hallways and indoor parks with open ceilings. Stone columns with a glittery, crystalline texture were spaced intermittently around the open space. Martha detected a faint buzzing as she passed them, although it wasn't unpleasant. She remembered the Doctor mentioning something about the minerals on this planet having psychic properties, and wondered if it was used in the treatment.

The people she saw were mostly staff, wearing the same white uniforms as Dr. Inga and her associates, but others were obviously patients. Many appeared older, but none were remotely fat as far as Martha could see. As outside, she was the largest person there simply by virtue of having visible flab. Flab which, she noticed self-consciously, jiggled with every step. She tried to peer around the two men flanking her to look around. She was already calmer just being there. A few patients glanced at her, and Martha thought she saw surprise in their eyes.

"It's the potbelly. They haven't seen someone with such an obvious one in a while, I suppose," one of the men said in a pleasant voice.

"Potbelly?" Martha said, yet more annoyance in her voice, as she cupped the quivering belly she still wasn't used to in her palm.

"Or your hips. Wider than usual, you know," the other said.

Martha scowled. Her hips, always a prominent feature of hers, had actually gathered very little of the weight that had pooled in her belly and ass. She then realized the two were flanking her as they were to hide her and prevent other patients from getting a good look at her. This came closer to angering Martha. They just assumed she was as ashamed of herself as they would be. True, Martha had always been thin, and assumed she always would be, but gaining a little weight was hardly debilitating injury. She was more upset with what it represented, her listlessness, growing laziness, and unrequited love leading her to depression, than she was with the weight itself. Of course, she would be more than happy to part with it.

They walked up to a stand where another staff member with a thin tablet stood.

"Martha Jones," Inga spoke quietly, "Here from the colonies. Height, 5'3", weight, 144 pounds-"

Here the clipboard-holding man's eyes went wide. He peered between the two nurses flanking Martha. Martha smiled smugly and waved. She was, however, pleased to hear that she had only gained twenty-four pounds, and not the dread round thirty she feared.

"--here for the five day total treatment. Can you please reserve a room and file the necessary work orders?" Inga smiled broadly, turning to Martha.

"Can we do her in five days?" the man said.

"Please, Irv, I'm sure she feels bad enough without your snide commentary" Inga snapped, then smiled back at Martha.

Irv shrugged, entering the information on his tablet.

"You are, as always, the boss, Dr. Inga," like everyone she heard here, Martha felt a strong disconnect between the silky voice the man had the words he said.

"Let me show you to your room, Ms. Jones," Inga said, dismissing the two others as she led Martha down a hallway.

"Here are the Paradise Health Clinic we know how important your body is to you, and we will do our best to return it to its natural state of beauty. How do you like the surroundings?"

"It's lovely," Martha said, and meant it. "So what does his involve?"

"Five days, Ms. Jones, is all we need. We will give you the finest, purest food, teach you the most basic exercises, and of course we will use our planet's own natural elements to ease your mind as well as your body. It will not feel like work at all. After your first day you will notice a difference."

Martha grabbed a few inches of flab around her waist, "A few days? It took a few months of binging to get this, I supposed five days is reasonable."

They entered a stark white room with a large, round bed and little furniture. Inga closed the door and motioned for Martha to sit.

"If it's not too hard to talk about it, please, could you tell me how it happened?"

"How it happened?" Martha repeated, unable to hide how ludicrous she found the question. "I was depressed, and I ate and bummed around my place. Nothing happened. I just made a pig of myself, is all. And I decided enough was enough. I wanted to make a change, get my life back together. So my friend, the Doctor, suggested here."

"A pig is something you don't want to be then?" Inga said, confused.

"Er, yes, it's an animal, from Earth-"

"Interesting," Inga seemed to make a mental note of it. Martha had gotten used to appreciating and accommodating alien cultures, but still forgot that some basic things she knew of Earth in her time might be forgotten by humans in the distant future. The door opened, and a young woman with a tray of food silently entered. Like the ubiquitous aroma that was calming Martha's nerves, the food had a scent that was so attuned to the surroundings that it barely registered as food in Martha's mind. It was just another pleasant sensation. At least it looked delicious. Some sort of vegetable dish, she knew, albeit with alien plants.

Inga stood up, looking outside at the sun setting quickly.

"Please enjoy your first dinner here, Ms. Jones," Inga said. "You'll find a dressing gown in the closet, and your other necessities should you need them."

Martha stood up to see her out.

"Thank you, Doctor," Martha said, "I do really appreciate this."

"It's nothing at all. It's what we live to do," Inga smiled. "Good night, Martha."

Inga left Martha to her meal, which she promptly consumed. It was not a large meal, but still left her satisfied. She had been stuffing herself so fully the last few months that being satisfied and not having to undo her jeans (which were already undone anyways) was an unfamiliar sensation. As she lay down, she found herself thinking of her med school days. She barely ate then with how engrossed with studying she was. As Martha drifted off to sleep, she found herself thinking more and more of herself. Images of herself, before her current gain, drifted through her mind, wearing outfits she thought looked good on her, or would if she hadn't outgrown them. It struck her as strange, but then, given the circumstances, she dismissed the strangeness and drifted off to a dreamless sleep.

Running her hands over her flabby body uncertainly, Donna sighed sadly. She didn’t appear to be too badly off. After all, she travelled with the Doctor, for crying out loud. The job of being his companion (and she did sometimes consider it a full time job keeping him out of trouble) required a lot of running away from horrible monsters and evil dictators and their brain-dead minions. When she reached the dome-shaped coral-lined room, she looked around for any sign of the Doctor. She saw his brown suit jacket slung over the back of the jump seat, but she couldn’t see its owner anywhere.

“Doctor?” she called out.

“Donna?” his voice responded.

Donna walked around to the other side of the console and looked down. There was a section of the grilled floor missing, and she could just make out a familiar head of sticky-uppy brown hair poking out of it. She chuckled to herself.

“What the hell are you doing to this poor ship now?” she demanded.

“She was making a strange humming sound. Just trying to determine the source. I think it might be something to do with the thermo couplings and their linkage to the helmic regulator.”
“Oh, simple as that, eh?”

“Incredibly simple,” the Doctor replied with a smile evident in his voice.

“Need any help?”

“No… Well, maybe… Yes. There’s a button on the console. Could you press it for me?”

Donna blinked. She looked at the console. There were about six different panels going all the way around, and each one had several buttons on it. “Which button, genius? There’s about fifty per panel, here.”

The Doctor sighed. “The third on in the sixth row on the first section of the panel directly in line with the doors,” he replied irritably.

Donna’s temp brain memorized the directions exactly, and she set to work on the console. She lined herself up with the doors and found the correct button, stabbing it with her index finger.

There was a brief moment of silence.

“Was that right?” she asked.

“Yeah… This is odd. It doesn’t seem to be working. Try the second button on the third section of that panel.”

Donna did so.

The response was a shower of sparks that erupted from under the floor. Donna wasn’t sure at first, but it seemed to be coming from the Doctor’s section. She knew for certain when he let out a yelp in surprise.

“Ouch! Blimey…!”

“You alright, Spaceman?” she asked, trying not to laugh.

“Yeah, I’m fine. Just burnt,” he replied. “That wasn’t right… Are you sure you pressed the right button?”

“Well, how am I supposed to know if it’s the right button? It’s your time machine, matey!”

She heard a tired sigh. “Fair enough… Okay, change of plans! We’ll swap!”

“…We’ll what?”

“Come on! I know that console like the back of my glasses. You stay down here and just hold the thick black cable in place, and I’ll deal with things up top.”

Donna sighed irritably, but she went with it. “Alright, come on, you,” she said, heading for the open section of the floor.

The Doctor pulled himself out of the hole, and Donna stifled a giggle when she saw that the end of his tie was smoldering. He shot her a warning gaze and headed for the console.
Donna removed the coat she’d put on and set it aside before getting down and slowly lowering herself into the hole. She was halfway down when she realized it was a bit of a squeeze. Granted, she’d never been down in the TARDIS’s inner-workings before, but it had looked like a fairly large hole from above it. Now that she was within it, it was beginning to feel a bit claustrophobic. She closed her eyes and took a big intake of breath as quietly as she could, sucking in her girth. She found herself slotting in almost perfectly.

Sighing with relief, she let out her breath, and she was dismayed by the fact that her stomach had begun to push against the massive amounts of circuitry and wiring. She was pleased to find, however, that the thick black cables were easy to find. She worked around and grabbed hold of them and held them together.

“Okay, I’ve got them in place,” she said. “What’ve I got to do now?”

“I just need to find the right sequence of buttons and switches that will rectify the power fluctuations and redirect the excessive power into the helmic regulator. Won’t take a tic!”
“Just don’t set me on fire.”

She heard a flurry of clicks as the Time Lord began working the console in madman fashion. She twisted her head round as much as she could to witness his silhouette against the glow of the console practically dancing around the console, flicking switches and pushing buttons with an unbridled glee on his face.

She watched him in amazement. He really was daft sometimes, but then there were times like this when he was absolutely brilliant.

Not that she’d ever tell him that, of course.

She was so mesmerized by this that she was taken by surprise when he suddenly stopped, slammed a lever, and all the lights suddenly came on, and there he was, striking a pose.

And… we’re back to daft, she thought to herself, rolling her eyes.

The Doctor took a bow. “Well done!” he exulted. “Right then, that’s the old girl sorted! Time to have a bit of fun!”

“Fun?” Donna asked. “What’s that include? Running from more of those Sontarans? Fighting some huge green slimy monster that feeds on desire? Fixing some ‘timey-wimey’ thing that endangers all of creation?”

“Right then, come on!” he declared, rounding the console and grabbing his trench coat off the piece of coral he always slung it over. “One fish, two fish…?”

“No, no, that was in the future with Shakespeare – way in the future. About fifteen years, give or take. Won’t have happened yet. I don’t think. Maybe. Shall we?”

Donna sighed. “How shall we? Do we have to dress up?”

“Oh, I suppose a little bit of dress-up couldn’t hurt,” he replied. “Let’s hit the wardrobe room. If we’re quick, we’ll be just in time for the dancing!”

They headed up and around various corridors until they finally found the spiral staircase that took them up into the wardrobe room.

“Where’s the ladies’ section?” Donna asked.

“Down in that direction,” the Doctor replied, pointing off in the distance. “The TARDIS will help you. Just have a looksee.”

Donna nodded and headed in the direction he’d pointed in. She rounded a few corners and found herself surrounded by loads of dresses and skirts. She tutted to herself, wondering how the Doctor had acquired all these womens’ clothes in the first place. She knew he’d travelled with other women before, but it was a little strange that he just happened to have clothes that suited every location they landed in.

After going through a few, she found a red dress that was her size. It looked very posh indeed. She felt a girlish grin tugging at the corner of her mouth as she took it down and headed for the nearest changing room. She peeled off her stained shirt and her fat jeans and proceeded to slip into her new dress. It had poofy shoulders and was cut rather low in the front, but not too far. She didn’t trust all those men from the Elizabethan era.

Finally, she had to put on the very last piece – the corset. She sighed to herself. Her recent binge probably hadn’t done her any favors. She wrapped it around her midsection and proceeded to take a deep breath and suck in her gut. She tied it up as fast as she could.

Once she was done, she looked like she was thirty pounds lighter – or she would’ve, if it weren’t for the little bulges of fat trying to escape through the material.

“Oof,” she sighed, taking a labored breath. “You better hold together…”

Moving rather awkwardly, she left the changing room and walked up the gangway towards the control room. Her sneakers clanked the entire way. If there was one thing she had learned from the Doctor, it was that it paid to have a pair of good running shoes.

She found him already there, going over some controls. He was wearing a very smart-looking suit that was made up of a velvet jacket, black trousers and a cravat.

“Oooh, look at you,” she cooed, looking him up and down.

The Doctor grinned. “I haven’t dressed like this for a few bodies,” he murmured. “Right then – ready?”

She held out a hand. “Lead the way, kind sir,” she replied.

The Doctor took her hand and led her down the ramp and through the doors.

They walked out into a very welcoming atmosphere. There was lots of laughter and singing and music going on just outside.

The TARDIS had evidently landed in a stable near the festivities, but they could see activity occurring nearby.

“Looks like we’re just in time for some fun,” the Doctor grinned. “This way, I think!”

Donna looked around, her grin growing larger as they walked along. There were loads of Elizabethan party-goers all walking around, playing games and dancing.

Suddenly, she found herself in the middle of a rather spirited dance with a group of people, all of them taking turns twirling her and various other women around. She became disoriented and tried hard to keep up, not to mention locate the Doctor.

All this movement was causing her to jiggle all over, and she could feel her breasts bouncing madly, almost threatening to burst out, and she was beginning to wish she’d done a better job tying this thing up. She was spun around in several directions, growing dizzy.

Finally, she found herself being thrust into a faintly familiar-looking suit, and she looked up to find the Doctor grinning down at her.

“Having fun, Donna?” he asked innocently.

“…Oh… I’ll let you know as soon as there’s only one of you…”

The Doctor laughed heartily. “Come on. What say we find some dinner. Sample the local cuisine?”

Donna’s stomach rumbled. “Ohh, you read my mind.”

“Well…”

“…Wait, you didn’t, did you?”

“Never! Only in the direst of emergencies, like when your birthday’s coming up or something,” he said quickly.

Donna rolled her eyes. “Alright, let’s not talk about my age. Let’s see what they’ve got for nibbles.”

The Doctor looped his arm through hers, and they headed inside, where they found the dining room, where various people were gathered around a massive table.

Donna’s mouth fell open at the large amounts of food that were piled upon the table. There were huge amounts of meat, vegetables and desserts that made her drool.

“Oh my God, look at all that!” she exclaimed.

“Well, they need enough to feed all the whole party,” the Doctor replied with a shrug. “Come on.”

The Doctor and Donna grabbed a pair of plates and began to load them up with food. While the Doctor was loading up, he became distracted by all the people who were talking to him at once, trying to include him in their conversations, and the Doctor ended up trying to come up with a cover story for who they were and why they were invited.

Donna let him do just that. While he was trying to figure everything out, she was piling more and more food onto her plate. She had loads of chicken, beans, pork, carrots, peas, and various other things that she wanted to sample while she had the chance that most humans in her day and age never got to try.

Finally, the Doctor managed to get away from the crowds, and she sat down with him at one of the tables.

“Fascinating people,” he said to himself. “Rather nosey, but very talkative.”

“What’d you tell them?” Donna asked with her mouth full.

“That I’m the Lord of Gallifrey, and I’m here with my sister from Chiswick.”

“Sister?” Donna asked.

“Why not? You’d rather I was your husband?”

“Not in a million years.”

“There we are, then.”

“Good call.”

The Doctor began to eat his dinner as well. “Managed to find out what else is scheduled for today,” he went on. “There’re going to be fireworks later tonight.”

“Sixteenth century fireworks?” Donna asked. “Can’t wait to see that.”

“Yeah, it should be a treat. Enjoying your dinner?”

“Oh my god, it’s gorgeous,” she replied through her full mouth. She’d already put a sizeable dent in her meal.

For half an hour, they sat there, talking and observing the local color.

Donna ended up going back for seconds, and then thirds, and then just a little bit of fourths. She kept eating more and more, absolutely loving the food and drink she was consuming, only somewhat aware of how full she was getting. Her stomach was trying to stretch outwards, but the corset was growing tighter and tighter around her mid-section, and the bulges of fat were working their way through.

Finally, it was night time, and before she knew it, the Doctor was leading her to a hill with some other people, and they were sprawled out in the grass, looking up at the amazing display of fireworks.

Donna lay back on the hill, resting her hair in the grass. She began to subtly undo the corset a little to relieve the pressure. As she admired the beauty of the colors in the sky, she rubbed her stomach, helping digestion take place. She sighed inwardly. She wasn’t about to lose weight any time soon.
13531.title: She's awoken by the Doctor, who wants to go...

choices: They travel to another planet.
They remain in the TARDIS for awhile.
135311.content:
The TARDIS door squeaked open, and the Doctor helped Donna through the threshold. She was just a little tipsy after partaking in the various ales available at the party – so much that his acute sense of hearing could almost hear her sloshing and gurgling as she moved. He kicked the door shut with his heel.

“Come on, Donna, we’re home,” he said, helping her with the step up onto the central section of the room.

“Home… My mother’s not here, is she?” Donna slurred.

“Hope not. I’ve never done well with mothers in the TARDIS…”

“Good. She’d just nag me about drinking too much.”

“Well, you did drink ten glasses…”

“Oi. Shut it, Martian Boy.”

The Doctor chuckled lightly. “Okay, okay… Why don’t you just head off to bed? The TARDIS should be able to help you find the way.”

Donna merely belched in reply.

The Doctor crinkled his nose. “Maybe she’ll help you find your toothbrush first,” he muttered, aiming her towards the internal door. “Goodnight, Donna.”

“‘Night, Spaceman,” Donna replied, waving behind herself as she waddled off down the corridor.

The Doctor chuckled and set about taking them back into the Time Vortex.

Donna, meanwhile, staggered off down the corridor, hoping dimly that she was on her way to her bedroom. As she walked, she slowly began to undo the corset, feeling it was very difficult for her to breathe with the blasted thing on. Bit by bit, as she found the doorway to her room, she began to undo the knots.

By the time she had opened her door and made it inside, she had just about gotten halfway through it when there was a sudden snapping noise, followed by several more, and she realized that her stomach was snapping through the remainder of the restraints, until finally it had made its way all the way forward.

Donna stared down at the various pieces of broken string that dangled around the globe that was her belly. She sighed unhappily to herself as he got the thing off and began to peel out of her dress. She got down to her underwear and headed for her private bathroom. Her feet were killing her, and she needed a bath.

She didn’t bother with the bathroom scale. She didn’t want to know. She simply got a nice hot bath going with lots of bubbles, and she tiredly waited on the side for it to fill up all the way.

Fifteen minutes later, she was lying on her back in the full tub, which was loaded with perfectly hot water and loads of suds. She settled back into it and relaxed. She let one hand drape outside of the tub, while the other one rested comfortably upon her store tummy, which grew and shrank with every strained breath.

For a long time, she just lie there, listening to her own digestion taking place.

Finally, after half an hour, she knew she needed to get out and go to bed, so she heaved herself out of the water and grabbed her softest bathrobe, wrapped it tightly around herself, and put on her softest slippers as well. She wrapped her hair up in a towel and padded over to the sink where she proceeded to brush her teeth, and then she headed towards her bed.

When she got there, she found a glass of water sitting on the nightstand. Silently thanking the TARDIS for her consideration, she took a long gulp from the glass before setting it down and lying down on the bed, hoping tomorrow’s hangover wouldn’t be so bad. Her stomach had settled for the most part, but there was still the odd gurgle emanating from it. She let out a small hiccup and rolled over again, listening to it slosh. She could feel her eyelids getting heavier and heavier until she finally drifted off to sleep.
135311.title: They return to the TARDIS.

1353111.title: They travel to another planet.

Donna and the Doctor arrive on a new planet.
1353112.content:
The weeks that ensued were quiet ones.

The Doctor was quite content to continue traveling around the universe, managing to take them to quiet places. But for the most part, they remained in the TARDIS.

Donna tried to stay active while they were in there. She tried to keep going to the gym and work out, but she found she was getting winded faster than she cared to. Then, to make matters worse, whenever she tried to go back, it was never in the same place twice. The Doctor simply said the TARDIS was in a playful mood, but Donna thought it was just torturing her.

One thing the old time machine had no shortage of was vending machines. They seemed to be popping up all over the place, sticking out of walls invitingly.

Donna tried to ignore them, and she managed to for at least five whole days. By day six, though, she realized that unless she took something from them at some point, she was probably going to starve, and of all the ways to get thin, that method appealed to her the least.

Sighing to herself on the sixth afternoon, she clutched her empty stomach mournfully and headed for the vending machine. It was in a secluded part of the TARDIS. The Doctor was off working on another one of his projects, so he’d be busy for some considerable time, and he most likely wouldn’t want to be disturbed.

She tried to order something healthy, but the machine seemed to be on the blink, because when she ordered a banana, she got a banana split. When she ordered an apple, she got an apple pie. When she ordered a glass of milk, she got a vanilla milkshake.

She looked at all the desserts that lay out before her and sighed heavily. Then she attempted reverse psychology. She ordered a large cheeseburger with everything. To her disappointment, that’s exactly what she got.

She looked up at the ceiling. “You’re trying to fatten me up, aren’t you?” she snapped irritably.

The TARDIS offered no reply.

Her stomach, however, gurgled hungrily.

Donna stared at everything sitting on the floor in front of her.

“Oh, all right, fine,” she grumbled. She picked up the burger and bit into it, feeling the grease dribble down her chin.

As if expecting this, a robotic hand extended from the machine and produced a paper napkin.

Donna rolled her eyes, took it, dabbed at her chin and took another bite.

Within five minutes, the entire burger was gone, washed down by the milkshake. She took a few slices of pie, followed by half the banana split, which took her a grand total of thirty minutes altogether.

Donna sat down on the floor, leaning against the wall, her legs sticking straight out and her hands on her belly, which protruded firmly in front of her.

“No more…,” she moaned. “I just can’t.”

The robotic arm extended again and produced a pair of antacids.

Donna snatched them away and popped them in her mouth. Much to her surprise, they worked rather quickly, and her tummyache subsided.

“Oooh,” she sighed. “Much better… Still can’t move, though…”

The robotic arm reached down and picked up the leftover ice cream. Donna thought it was merely clearing away the dishes, but to her surprise, a second robotic arm extended, picked up the spoon and scooped out a small scoop of half-melted ice cream.

Donna stared at it, wishing she was somewhere else.

Reluctantly, she opened her mouth, allowing the ice cream to be placed inside.

And then the robotic arms proceeded to feed her the ice cream. In no time, the entire thing had been emptied, with the remaining melted ice cream being poured down her throat.

Then it proceeded to the remaining apple pie. It took out slice after slice, letting Donna go at her own rate. It wasn’t long before the entire thing was gone.

Donna’s stomach protested against all this. She felt like she was going to explode.

Then, to her astonishment, the arms reached down, lifted up her shirt and undid the button on her trousers, allowing her swollen gut to expand to full capacity.

Donna would’ve been furious if it hadn’t felt so good. She just sat there, patting her belly, enjoying the fullness.

After a nice fifteen minute sit, she wanted to go to her room. The hands held themselves out to her, encouraging her to take hold. She did so, and she was startled when she was suddenly hoisted back up again. She wobbled a bit, but she was back on her feet. She turned and waddled off down the corridor, and she felt relieved when she found the door to her room was closer than it had been this morning.

She went inside and collapsed on the bed, listening to her recent gorge gurgle and slosh inside of her. She rolled over onto her back and patted her stomach with pleasure.

Just her luck. The TARDIS was a chubby chaser.
1353112.title: They remain in the TARDIS for awhile.

choices: They find a village.
They find a garden of giant fruit.
13531122.content:
The weeks passed.

The Doctor took Donna to all sorts of places, but to her surprise, they rarely found themselves doing any running. In fact, they had had some rather relaxing trips as of late, to all sorts of leisure centers where they didn’t have to do much of anything.

While Donna always had a good time at these places, the Doctor was beginning to get a little bit bored with always having an easy time.

And all the while, Donna found herself constantly be offered loads of calorie-loaded snacks from the TARDIS. She tried to turn them down, but she just couldn’t help herself sometimes. They were just so good.

Today, though, something interesting was about to happen.

The Doctor was inspecting the TARDIS’s circuitry, trying to figure out why the old girl was always taking them to nice, relaxing, boring locations. He managed to find an override system that would give them complete random coordinates. Not even his ship knew where they were going to land next.

As he was doing this, he didn’t notice Donna coming from behind him, finishing off a chocolate ice cream cone. She was just popping the last bit of it in her mouth when she came to a stop next to him.

“What’s up?” she asked through her chewing.

“I’ll tell you what,” the Doctor said with a grin. “We are going to a new exciting alien planet!”

“How’d you know that?”

“I don’t. I’ve set the controls to random. Completely random location! No idea where we’re going!”

“Same as usual then?”

“Oh yes!”

Donna chuckled. “How much longer ‘til we get there?”

“Not long. Should be any – whoa!”

The TARDIS suddenly lurched to the side, causing both passengers to fall to the floor.

The Doctor was back on his feet in an instant, working the controls.

Donna, however, was finding it a little tricky to stand up. She’d had more than an ice cream cone. She’d had five ice cream cones and a jumbo bag of chips. Her stomach gurgled as she found herself on top of it. Wincing in pain, she tried to roll over and get up, but it was a little difficult, considering how heavy she was feeling right now.

With a grunt, she managed to reach over and grab the edge of the jump seat. She gripped it as tight as she could, and with three gallant attempts, she managed to haul herself up onto it, where she turned around and sat down, clutching the sides, her whole body jiggling as the TARDIS shuddered and rocked.

Finally, the Doctor managed to find a way to slow everything down. With a loud THUMP the ship settled down, and all was still.

And after a few seconds, Donna’s flesh was still, too.

“Well!” the Doctor said, with a big childish grin. “Shall we?”

Donna nodded uncertainly as she shakily stood up. She was definitely curvier than she’d been before. Her breasts were a cup size larger, her rear swayed back and forth mesmerizingly, she was sprouting an extra chin, and her bulbous stomach was protruding rather far ahead of her.

But the Doctor didn’t seem to notice. Instead, he dramatically opened the doors and looked outside.

They were in a jungle.

The Doctor grinned. This looked promising.

“What do you think?” he asked excitedly.

Donna stared.

The jungle was huge. That probably went without saying, but everything in the jungle was HUGE. The plants, the trees – they all towered over her like giants. Even the smallest flowers there seemed bigger than her.

If ever there were a place that could make her feel thin, it was this place.

“It’s beautiful…”

The Doctor grinned and strode out into the open. Donna followed, absently closing the doors behind her.

“Is there anyone else here?” Donna asked.

“Dunno. Let’s find out.”

The Doctor proceeded to march straight ahead, digging his way through the vines and branches.

Donna waddled after, pleased to be walking a great distance and therefore burning calories.
13531122.title: Donna and the Doctor arrive on a new planet.

choices: She proceeds to devour the entire garden.
They are found by natives.
135311222.content:
They must’ve walked for fifteen minutes before they found themselves in a small clearing.

And in the middle of the clearing was the biggest garden Donna had ever seen.

The Doctor put on his glasses as they wandered down towards it. Somehow, the vines had all wound themselves around each other and were holding each other up, allowing them all to take in the sun.

“I love it!” the Doctor exclaimed. “Look at all this!”

Donna ran her fingers along the side of an orange-colored plant. “What are these?” she asked.

The Doctor pulled out his sonic screwdriver and scanned the plant in question. “Edible,” he said at last. “Don’t know the actual name, but it does show a low acidity factor, and curiously high in essential vitamins.”

“They’re huge!”

“Yes, they are. Well done.”

“Oi.”

“Well, everything else on the planet’s huge. It only stands to reason they’d grow at roughly the same rate.”

“Can I…? Can I try one?” Donna asked.

“Of course you can! Totally safe!”

Trying not to appear too eager, Donna wrapped her hands around the fruit – which was about the size of her head – and pulled it down from the vine. “How do I open it?”

The Doctor responded by aiming the sonic at the stem, which caused it to split, and then he proceeded to ‘unzip’ the plant.

“How’d you do that?” Donna asked. “How do you use a screwdriver to peel fruit?”

“Used the sonic vibrations to split the stem open. Are you gonna try it or not?”

Donna decided to just forgo the technobabble and dig in. She wasn’t really sure how to start, so she just turned her head to an angle and opened her mouth as wide as she could, taking a huge bite. She felt the juices dribble down her chin, but she didn’t care, because suddenly she was in heaven. She chewed and chewed and swallowed, and then took another bite, eagerly and ravenously.

As she was taking her fourth bite, the Doctor raised an expectant eyebrow. “Good, then?” he asked.

“It’sh Gorgoush!” Donna declared through her full mouth.

“Good. Swallow.”

Donna did so, feeling the huge amount of chewed fruit settle in her belly, feeling it stretch slightly from taking on so much at once.

“It’s the most incredible thing,” she said. “I’ve never had anything like it.”

The Doctor looked around at the other plants. There were different kinds of varying shapes, sizes and colors. “I wonder if there’re any banana-flavored ones,” he murmured.

Donna chuckled at him. She continued to snarf down the whole fruit with gusto, and after a few minutes, all that was left was the core, which she let drop to the ground carelessly before she tore into a different fruit.

It was a large green one, this time. She found this one to have the skin of an apple or a pear, so she simply bit into it. Once again, an explosion of flavor ripped across her taste buds and sent an unmistakable signal to her brain: “Eat! Eat! Eat! Eat!”

And so she did. Donna chomped down on the fruit with gusto, eating as much of it as she could. It took a few more minutes, but at last, all that was left was another core, which she once again tossed aside before looking around a little more.
135311222.title: They find a garden of giant fruit.

choices: The feast takes place.
Flash forward to their return to the TARDIS.
1353112222.content:
Donna proceeded to pluck a third fruit, from the vine, overcome with a greedy desire to eat every last scrap of fruit she could find, when she heard a noise coming from close by. She turned to look, not letting go of the large peach-like fruit in her arms. As she looked around, she took a bite from the fruit, enjoying its flavor while looking around curiously.

She was in the middle of her second bite when she heard the noise again, definitely behind her, and she turned around.

The Doctor was there with his hands up in surrender, and there was a small gaggle of what appeared to be warriors holding spears to his back.

“Er, Donna?” the Doctor said, trying not to sound too nervous. “Could you be a dear and tell these nice people that I have not come here to rape their land and defile their women?”

Donna blinked, chewed and swallowed. “He isn’t, you know,” she said to the natives. “Those are the very last things on his mind.” And she took another bite.

“Thank you!” the Doctor said with a grin. “She’s Donna Noble. You can take her word for it.”

The natives looked at each other uncertainly.

Finally, one of them, possibly their leader, lowered his spear, and then all the others lowered their spears.

He walked forward. He was fully dressed in skins, with tribal markings on his face, and his hair was wild and graying. He approached Donna cautiously, and she eyed him warningly, somehow managing to look authoritative even while slowly devouring a giant piece of fruit.

“You have eaten from the Sacred Garden,” he said at last.

Donna swallowed the last bit of fruit, and for some reason, this one felt heavier than the others. Her stomach began to quiver with fear, trying to contain the large amount of fruit it had just been tasked to hold.

“Sacred Garden?” she asked nervously.

“Yes,” the tribe leader said. “And they say those who eat from the Sacred Garden are to be worshiped and obeyed.”

And all the tribesmen got down on their knees and proceeded to bow before Donna.

The Doctor looked rather peculiar, sticking out of the group of kneeling people. He looked over at Donna and shrugged with a bemused expression on his face.

Donna looked bemused right back.

“So,” she said at last. “You, er, worship people who eat from the garden, eh?”

“Yes, my lady,” the leader replied from the ground.

“…Why’s that? What’s so important about this garden?”

Now he looked up. “You do not know?”

“Afraid not.”

“Those who eat from the plants and live must have otherworldly powers. Only a goddess such as yourself could survive these plants.”

And they began to chant some sort of holy prayer.

The Doctor managed to slip out of the field of people’s backs and made it over to her. “Not bad for a temp,” he said under his breath.

“Cheeky,” Donna replied. “What’s he talking about? Are the fruits dangerous or not?”

“They’re not. I’m sure of it. It must be something else. Maybe it’s their biology and they can’t digest the fruit. Maybe someone made up the legend to keep these people away from here. I’m not sure.”

Suddenly, the tribe leader was on his feet again. “Goddess, you must command us!”

Donna looked surprised. “Why’s that?”

“You are a divine holy messenger! You have come to show us the way!”

Donna blinked. She looked at the Doctor, but he was just grinning away, loving this. She wrinkled her nose at him and looked at them.

“Well… what have you all been doing so far?” she asked.

“We hunt. We gather. We raise our young so that they may learn to hunt and gather.”

“And is that it?”

“Is there more?”

Donna sighed. It wasn’t really her place to change these people’s lifestyles. “Just…keep on doing what you’re doing,” she assured them. “You’ve been going the right way all along.”

“We… We have?”

“Yes. You have good lives. You don’t need me to show you anything. You’ve had the answers inside you all along.”

The tribe leader stared at her.

Then he turned to his people, held up his hands and shouted, “The Goddess has spoken!”

And they all erupted into cheers.

Donna sighed with relief.

“Not bad, Goddess,” the Doctor chuckled.

“You better believe it, Time Boy,” she replied, smugly crossing her arms over her chest.

“Come!” the tribe leader declared. “We shall have an enormous feast in your honor!”

Donna stared at them. She let her arms uncross and cradle her belly, which was still rather full from all that fruit. “Ohh, I dunno…”

“Oh, come on, Goddess!” the Doctor said eagerly. “Can’t we stay? Please?”

Donna glared at him for a moment before sighing. “Oh, very well,” she sighed.

The tribesmen cheered again, and they began to lead the Doctor and Donna towards their city.

Donna began wishing she’d worn elastic.
1353112222.title: They are found by natives.

choices: The TARDIS continues to fatten her up
They make a trip to see her family
13531122222.content:
It was the longest day of Donna's life - which it might've been, what with it being an alien planet and all. So much feasting. When they said feast, they really meant it. She was so stuffed as she followed the Doctor back to the TARDIS. Not that he'd noticed. He'd spent most of his time helping to defeat a so-called "god" that was terrifying the natives. Turned out to be a genetic mutation that had been dumped on their world decades ago. With the creature neutralized and the people saved, they'd been very grateful and treated like heroes.

The Doctor was still talking a mile a minute about god knows what, but Donna was just waddling after him. Her pants were unbuttoned, but they were in no danger of falling. Her stomach stuck out so far ahead of her that they didn't budge. She waddled after the Doctor as they entered the TARDIS. He was still talking. Where did he find the energy?

Donna sat down on the jumpseat and got her large posterior as comfortable as possible. She sat back and rubbed her stomach. She was almost certain she would burst. She rubbed and rubbed while the Doctor set the TARDIS in flight and back into the vortex.

"Well!" the Doctor said cheerfully. "That was good fun! Maybe we'll go back there someday!"

Donna hiccuped. "Yeah... someday...," she moaned, leaning back. "Blimey... I can't believe I ate it all."

"They were impressed! Said only a goddess could pack it away like that!"

"They did?"

"... I'm paraphrasing, but that's what they meant."

Donna rolled her eyes but smirked fondly. "God, look at me. Don't know how I'm going to move from this seat."

"Well, you're more than welcome to stick around."

"I just wanna fall asleep."

The Doctor turned and disappeared behind the console. She heard the sound of the metal grating he called a floor being lifted, and a moment later, it slammed shut, and he returned with a neck pillow. "Here you are! Try that on for size."

She smiled gratefully and slipped it on. God, that felt good. She put her hands under her enormous belly and rubbed it. "So go on, then. Say something science-y. Should put me right to sleep."

The Doctor gave her a stern look but continued working and talking anyway. She knew that he just needed someone to hear him talk sometimes. It's what she felt he needed from her the most - to not be lonely. She snuggled into the seat and rubbed her belly, drifting off to sleep.
13531122222.title: Flash forward to their return to the TARDIS.

choices: Dinner is served
Sylvia nags Donna about her weight
135311222222.content:
The Doctor made it a point to bring Donna home periodically so she could see her mother and grandfather. He'd experienced his companions drifting away from their normal lives too often and wanted to ensure that she still had a life on Earth. Living with her family, she had no rent to pay or anything, and her chronic unemployment meant she remained free to gad about the universe without being missed too much. Still, they agreed that they would try to arrive a week or two after her departure, regardless of how long she'd really been away, if only to reassure her family that she remained safe and not-dead.

Of course, her mother didn't know about all the zooming around space and time. Donna knew Sylvia would never approve of her misadventures. Her nagging would be cranked up to eleven, and it already seemed to routinely be at ten and a half anyway. The last thing she needed was Sylvia Noble's patented brand of "intrusive parent" sticking her nose into her already stressful life as it was.

Picking out an outfit for reuniting with them proved difficult. After a few more heavy fat meals in the last few months, her belly stuck out whether she was stuffed or not. It jiggled vertically and horizontally, mesmerizing passers by. She'd had to adjust her wardrobe accordingly six times now, going up many trouser sizes. It had become such a normal part of her life now that she had to admit she'd gotten used to gaining weight. What with all the running for her life that came with a standard life in the TARDIS, she hadn't really worried too much about it. She made sure to get some healthy food in with the junk food.

Of course, now she would have to face her domineering mother, and she knew she would never let that sort of thing off the hook. To have ballooned like this in the months she'd been away, only to come home a few weeks after her last visit, she didn't know what to do. She looked over her clothes in the hopes that she might find something less revealing. Something to take the focus off her gut, or at least disguise it.

Then, she found something she'd hoped she'd never see again -- the girdle from when they'd gone to the Middle Ages. Okay, the official name was a "corset", but all she could think of it was it helped make Captain Kirk look svelte on Star Trek. She looked down at her bowling ball of a belly and sighed with cold dread. Just power through it, she thought. You're only staying for dinner. That's all it was. In, out, a few hours, a cup of tea or two, and then back to the bigger-on-the-inside phone box to let her flab fly free.

Grimacing, she slipped it on, finding it difficult to get over her belly, but she sucked it in as best she could until the corset fit neatly around her enlarged middle. With all her might, she started tying it up. She'd just wear something bulky like a sweater to make it less noticeable. After a few minutes, she had it ready. She slipped on a thick dark blue sweater and a pair of her fat jeans and posed momentarily for the mirror. Frowning, she made sure the girdle wasn't too noticeable. She looked a little lumpy, she supposed, but at least her gut didn't protrude... quite as much. Taking a deep breath -- but not too deep -- she moved awkwardly out of the wardrobe room.

The Doctor brought the TARDIS in for a landing with minimal bumps and checked the readings. "Right!" he said triumphantly. "Chiswick! 2009! Home to Facebook, smart phones and the last half-decent season of The Big Bang Theory!"

"Never heard of that," Donna replied bluntly.

"For the best. You're not missing out on much." Then, his head tilted like it always did when he was bemused. "Are you all right?"

"Fine! Why do you ask?"

"Well, your breathing seems a bit... awkward."

Damn alien senses. "I'm fine. I'm just... wearing a little extra support under this sweater."

"Support?"

"Well... I've gained weight, and I'd rather my mum didn't notice, so I thought I'd just... hide the evidence?"

The Doctor looked her up and down before his eyes lit up. "Ohhhh!" he exclaimed. "I didn't notice there seemed to be less of you! Sorry, not the sort of thing I normally look at."

"I know, and I'm glad. That's what friends are for."

The Doctor smiled and prepared to open the doors. "Ready?"

"Never. But let's do this."

He pulled open the doors, revealing they were in a lot just down the street from her house. She knew her Gramps would want a look at an actual alien space ship one day, but it would have to be on a day when her mum wasn't about. They trudged up the sidewalk until they were walking up to the house. Not even bothering to knock, Donna pushed the door open and poked her head in.

"We're here!" she called out. "Mum? Gramps?"

"'ello, sweet'art!" Gramps called from the kitchen. "We just put the kettle on!"

Smiling at her grandfather's voice, Donna moved hurriedly into the kitchen and gave the old man a peck on the head. "How've you been, Gramps?" she asked.

"Not too bad, considering," he replied.

"Considering what?"

A shrill voice cut through the air. "Donna?!"

"Oh, that."

Sylvia came into the kitchen, looking a bit frazzled. She barely held back a scowl when she saw the Doctor. "Oh, you brought him, did you?"

"Hello," the Doctor said, waving slightly.

"Yes, mum, he's my friend," Donna said with an eye roll.

Sylvia still eyed him with great suspicion. "Funny how we don't know anything about this 'friend', isn't it?"

"Oh, leave it, luv," Wilf scolded. "I'm just glad our Donna has a friend she can rely on in her life."

"Thanks, Gramps," Donna said gratefully. "Now how about that cuppa?"

"Brilliant idea," the Doctor agreed. "Wilf -- how's the telly working?"

"Better since you tinkered with it. Although, I'm still getting the hang of that new remote control you built. Keep getting a channel called the 'Venusian Home Shopping Network'."

"Ah, might have extended the range a bit far. I'll fiddle with it before I leave."

Donna bit back a smile. If only he were husband material. But then again, she felt she needed a friend more than a husband anyway. She helped get the tea together, keeping her breathing nice and even as she got out the sugar and honey.

"Not taking yours with sugar now, are you?"

"No, mum, just a bit of honey. That's all. The sugar's for him. He can't drink it unless it rots his teeth out."

Sylvia nodded distantly, glancing back at the Doctor as he chatted with Wilf before readdressing Donna. "So what are you up to these days?"

"Oh, you know -- just traveling."

"With him?"

"Yes, with him. What's wrong with that? It's more fun with a mate."

"Well, as long as you're taking care of yourself. I don't want you falling apart out there without me to keep an eye on you."

Donna smirked. "Mum, I feel as though you're watching me no matter where I go."

Sylvia thankfully didn't realize that wasn't strictly a compliment and sat down at the table while Donna poured the tea for everyone. She passed out the cups and went to take her seat in the sole empty chair.

She immediately regretted this. She felt the corset struggle as her stomach bulged against it. She winced slightly as she tried to lower herself naturally into the chair.

Thankfully, the Doctor was talking a mile a minute about re-configuring a hairdryer into a particle accelerator, so nobody was really paying attention to her. She eased herself down into the chair, hoping to disguise the fact that she sat perfectly straight in her seat, her legs at an awkward angle.

This was going to be a long day after all.

1353112222221.content:
The day went by fairly uneventful. The Doctor and Donna regaled Wilf with the adventures they'd had lately. Zooming around time and space, fighting monsters, saving planets and running away from danger had given them plenty of stories to tell, and he held onto every word.

Meanwhile, Sylvia had been largely forgotten, mainly because she'd been toiling away in the kitchen, making dinner. Donna had long since given up trying to help her mother cook. She never seemed to get it right. Every attempt ended in criticism. So now she just hung out in the living room with her gramps and ignored it. Of course, then her mother would complain about doing all the work, but hey, at least it was less for Donna to do.

At last, she heard that shrill voice call out. "All right, it's ready! Come and get it!"

Donna awkwardly got to her feet, feeling the corset under her clothes groan slightly at her stomach attempting to bulge behind it. Thankfully, it held together, and she followed the others into the kitchen. Her mouth about fell open at the spread before them. Roast chicken, green beans, mashed potatoes, devilled eggs...

Wilf whistled. "Good grief, Sylvia luv, that had to take a bit of work."

Sylvia shrugged as she wiped her hands with a rag. "Well, you know how it is when we have guests over. Never know how much to make."

"And it looks amazing, Mrs. Noble," the Doctor said politely as he joined them at the table.

Despite her attempts to look like she didn't care, Sylvia still grinned slightly. "All right, you lot. Dig in."

Donna bit her lip slightly as she picked up her fork. She already felt like a sausage crammed into a tin with this corset on. She didn't need even more pressure. Perhaps she could get away with keeping it light. But it all looked so good...

As the Doctor passed her the mashed potatoes, she found herself scooping a hearty spoonful onto her plate. She'd just go easy on everything else.

Except she didn't, because she kept piling more on as it came around to her. Her plate loaded to maximum capacity, she winced to herself. For a woman who nagged her about her weight, her mother really shouldn't be so good a cook.

Conversation carried on to the latest gossip around town, with her family giving her updates on the various friends and neighbors and what they'd been up to lately. Pretty tame stuff compared to traveling through time and fighting monsters, but she knew she needed to experience the tedious monotony of the universe as well as the exciting bits. She chatted away with her family, the Doctor throwing in the odd question here and there, and soon, she began to forget how much she ate.

Unfortunately, about twenty minutes later, she began to feel the swell in her stomach grow against the corset. She squirmed in her seat as she felt it dig into her flesh. She really needed to stop eating, but to do so would leave uneaten food on her plate, and her mother would only take that as an insult. She forced herself to keep at it. She ate every last scrap of food on her plate while still holding together a half-decent conversation with everyone.

An hour passed, and at last, dinner ended.

Donna felt like she would explode.

Her stomach pressed hard against the corset, which she feel straining against her. She swallowed down a belch and set about helping tidy up.

"Well, that went well," Sylvia remarked as she washed the dishes. "Don't know why we don't do this more often."

Donna smiled wryly. "Yeah, well, maybe don't say 'oh, it's you' every time I have him over, eh?"

"No promises."

Washing up took another ten minutes, and each one seemed to pass slower than the last as Donna kept herself moving. Her stomach gurgled angrily, demanding breathing room at once. Sighing heavily, she pretended to check her watch the minute the last plate went into the cupboard.

"Well, that's the time," she said. "Better get back before I completely fall asleep."

Sylvia shrugged. "Well, all right then. But I'd like you to call more than just once a week," she said, awkwardly hugging her.

"Oh, I'll try," she said in a fake annoyed voice.

She waddled to the living room and fetched the Doctor. He'd managed to finish repairing the TV remote and had spent the evening showing Wilf some of the more human channels. She gave him a hug and promised to call him at her next destination before hurrying out the door with the Doctor.

"Why the rush?" he asked.

"Can't breath with this bloody thing on," Donna gasped as they made their way. "Why the hell did you park so far away?!"

The Doctor sighed and followed her up the street back to the empty lot where they'd left the TARDIS. Once they got there, she waited impatiently as he got out the key and unlocked it.

"Right then, all a -- oop!"

Donna pushed past him and got inside, immediately reaching under her sweater. She pulled on the knots and began to breathe a little easier as she felt her stomach expand with relief. She didn't even care when the resulting expansion caused the button to pop off her trousers. Her sweater rode up, and her full belly pooched forwards proudly.

The Doctor didn't seem all that concerned. He just stood off to the side, hands in pockets. "Better?"

"So much," she sighed. "God, that was the longest dinner of my life."

"Really? I thought it was one of my better interactions with your mother."

Donna smiled. "Yeah, I think she's coming 'round to you." She plopped down on the jumpseat, hands atop her belly. "God, I'm exhausted. I swear, I need a place where I can just relax for a while."

The Doctor thought about that for a moment, and then he smiled. "There's a planet I've always wanted to visit," he grinned, already working the controls. "I've heard it's one of the best leisure planets in the universe."

"Oh yeah?" Donna asked sleepily. "What are the odds the TARDIS will actually take us there?"

He frowned. "Well, she won't with that attitude."

"All right, all right, sorry," she chuckled. "What's the planet called?"

"Midnight! Almost made entirely of diamonds! You can relax to your heart's content!"

Donna pondered. "Will I have to wear trousers?"

"Almost certain they give you a bath robe the minute you get there."

She pointed a finger at him. "Book it."

He grinned and started inputting the coordinates.

13531122222211.content:
When Donna woke up next, she found herself in her room. She briefly wondered if the Doctor had carried her here, but she also knew the possibility of the TARDIS simply "putting" her there could be just as likely. Either way, she enjoyed a good night's sleep, rolled out of bed and got on her fat pants. She had to admit -- it felt great to breathe normally for a change. She took in her profile in the full-length mirror and shook her head. Her stomach still protruded outwards like she had swallowed a bowling ball. If she kept this up, her fat pants probably would be replaced by a pair of "fatter pants". It would get extra difficult hiding this from her mother.

Once she'd gotten dressed and done her hair up a bit, she made her way down to the control room. The Doctor stood at the console's monitor, typing away on a keyboard with his brainy specs on.

"Morning," she said, walking over to him.

"Gooooood morning," he replied, not looking up.

She pouted slightly at his lack of looking at her. She walked up behind him and put her chin on his shoulder, looking down at the screen. "Whatcha working on?"

"Our reservations on the planet Midnight. Told you about this last night, remember?"

"Oh yeah," she grinned. "Pleasure planet, right?"

His nose crinkled. "No, relaxation planet. Pleasure planet is something else entirely."

"Ooooh, can we go to one of them?"

He rolled his eyes, making her grin.

"You're such a prude," she sighed dramatically, walking off and plopping down on the jumpseat, ignoring how loudly it creaked under her considerable rump.

"And here we are!" he said triumphantly, finishing up. "Reservations booked! We're all set!"

"Great. So when do we leave?"

He just grinned excitedly before running down the ramp and opening the door.

Donna sat up a little straighter at the white light that poured in. She got up and scurried down after him, peering out the doors. "Oh my god, we're already here?!"

"Sent the reservation back through time," he explained. "Which means, we should be receiving a greeting right about..."

At that moment, a humanoid woman in a white uniform and a pleasant smile walked up, holding out a pair of white bathrobes to them. "Doctor John Smith, and Miss Donna Noble," she smiled. "Welcome to the Midnight Spa and Relaxation Center. Here are your customary robes."

Donna got over her shock -- plus her relief that they hadn't been mistaken for a married couple -- and took her robe.

"I shall show you to your rooms," the woman continued, leading them away.

They followed her into the complex, the Doctor making sure the TARDIS locked behind him.

"Separate rooms," Donna whispered.

"With adjoining doors," he replied.

"Good call."

They soon arrived at their rooms. Donna popped inside and immediately gaped at the place. Queen-sized adjustable bed with massage feature, big screen TV with an easy-to-understand remote, huge bath tub in the corner with a shower feature and a small balcony that overlooked the diamond world.

"It's gorgeous," Donna murmured.

Silence. She turned around.

"Doctor?"

Suddenly, the interior door swung open, and in walked the Doctor, his bathrobe on over his suit like his usual trench coat, and carrying a small jar. "Ooh, Donna, look -- macadamia nuts!"

She couldn't help but laugh. He could be such a child sometimes.

"This place is amazing," she sighed.

"I know! I've always wanted to visit! You know, the sun it orbits emits phenomenally lethal X-tonic radiation and there is no atmosphere. Exposure to the surface for even a split second would result in the unfortunate person being instantly vaporized."

Donna blinked, then looked outside. "So... why am I not?"

"The leisure facility is encased in a fifteen-inch-thick glass dome."

"Oh. Well, that's good, then."

"Quite. Gosh, there's just so much to do around here, I don't know what to do first."

"Well, I came here for some relaxation," Donna reminded him. "Not a load of running up and down corridors, even if it's only to the tourist shops."

The Doctor nodded understandingly. "Ask, and you shall receive," he said, pulling a brochure out of his pocket and handing it to her. "Came with the room. All the attractions in the facility -- restaurants, games, shows, relaxation..."

Donna opened the brochure and let out an impressed whistle. "It all looks good. Don't know how we'll cram it all in."

"Well, between the two of us, we can cover a lot of ground. Personally, I like the look of the anti-gravity restaurant, and then there's the diamond-cutting demonstration..."

"I have a hard time picturing you sitting still for one of those."

He shrugged. "Well, y'know, they might learn something from me."

Donna chuckled. "Well, I need to change first, and then I need to kick back for a bit. You can catch the show, and we'll meet up later."

"Sounds good. Where are you going to go?"

Donna looked at the brochure again.

135311222222111.content:
Clad in her bathrobe and very comfortable pair of walking shoes, Donna made her way through the complex, nodding politely to all the other people in white bathrobes as she followed the map on the brochure. She wondered if this could be considered "self-destructive behavior". After worrying about her weight so much, it felt counter productive to go to an all-you-can-eat buffet and pig out.

Of course, I won't pig out, she told herself. I'll behave myself. I just want to experience an alien culture that no other human being on Earth will ever see. At least, not in my lifetime. Hell, I probably won't even like half of it. Just gotta be sensible.

Repeating this to herself mentally, Donna finally found the Midnight Buffet. The opening resembled the entrance to a fancy restaurant in a shopping mall, but with large booths and plenty of room.

The receptionist at the front desk smiled pleasantly when she walked up. "Table for one?" she asked.

"Yes, please," Donna replied politely, showing her a plastic payment card the Doctor had given her.

The receptionist rang it up and directed her towards the buffet line. "Help yourself and enjoy!" she said, handing it back.

Donna smiled and grabbed a large tray. Keep it simple, she told herself. Just having a late breakfast. Or an early lunch. Whatever.

She got into line and felt her nostrils flare at the scrumptious smells wafting her way.

Maybe both.

Some of the food looked vaguely familiar, but others looked quite bizarre. Still, she couldn't help but marvel at how delicious most of it still looked. Still, she thought, just because something looked good didn't mean it was, in fact, good. She'd been led astray by normal-looking food in the past. Tomatoes, for example. They looked perfectly edible from the outside, but then, you got inside and found a lot of jiggly jelly-looking stuff. Not appetizing in the slightest.

Nevertheless, she'd make a go of it. Just a few small samples here and there. She scooped up something that looked like beans, followed by some blue stuff, then some stuff that looked vaguely like cannolis, something that resembled a buffalo wing, and a beverage that looked neon orange but had the most delightfully fizzy bubbles.

She looked at the heap of food on her plate. So this would be breakfast and lunch for the day then.

As she made her way to a small booth not far away, she took a moment to look at the crowd. Mostly human, or humanoid anyway, but some obvious aliens milled about, chatting amiably with everyone. She also couldn't help noticing just how large a lot of these people more. All of them with bulging bellies all protruding as they tucked into their meals. Several of them got up and went for more, despite how badly they waddled. It made Donna feel just that bit more secure about her own size -- she looked downright skinny compared to them.

With that happy thought, she settled into a booth and tucked into the food. She tried the weird-looking stuff first. To her surprise, it tasted like raspberry ice cream. Pleased at a familiar taste and texture, she continued to spoon it into her mouth. In fact, it seemed as though a lot of the food tasted like something back on Earth. Perhaps the food had been genetically modified or something to be more appealing to humans.

In any case, she plowed right through the meal and gobbled it down in minutes flat. Soon, an empty plate sat before her with the remnants of her meal. She took one last sip of the fizzy orange drink and leaned back in the booth. Making sure no one was watching, she loosened the belt on the robe a notch. She felt very full. She licked her lips and took another glance at the buffet line. Still plenty to go around.

... What the hell? she thought, and grabbed her tray for round two.

With so many options, it'd be a crime not to try a few more, she reasoned. She loaded her tray again and returned to her booth, eating it all down in nothing flat. She went back a third time and got much bigger helpings. More refills on that orange drink. More piles of that blue raspberry stuff. More food for her already-too-full belly. She chomped her way through it, losing the ability to care how much she had.

An hour later, though, she had to give in. She'd definitely had enough. Six trips through the buffet in total, and each time, she'd had to adjust the belt on her fluffy bathrobe ever-so-slightly. She lounged in the booth for a long time. She imagined she looked like she had swallowed a bowling ball, pressing against the table now.

Soon, she realized she couldn't just sit there -- not with the belt on the robe about to give any second. With a miserable grunt, she heaved herself out from the booth and dragged her way to the exit.

"Hope you had a good time, ma'am!" the receptionist called out cheerfully.

Donna managed a dazed smile in her direction but reserved her energy for getting back to her room. Her stomach gurgled and churned as it struggled to digest everything. It jiggled horizontally and vertically with every footstep. She needed to get back to the room, if only so she could rub some of the pain away.

At last, she staggered up to her door and inserted the room key. Once inside, she immediately shut the door and let the belt on the robe pop open. She gave a huge sigh of relief as her belly jiggled outwards and sagged heavily.

Her eyes scanned the room, and then she noticed the in-ground bathtub in the corner. Smiling to herself, she grabbed a pillow and lowered her bloated self into the bath, and then started the warm water. Adding some bubble bath, she got comfortable on the tub's seat and leaned back, enjoying the sound of the water running as it filled up the bath. She smiled dopily as it rushed up over her ankles and along her legs. She put her hands atop her belly and smiled beatifically as she became slowly submerged. Once it was up to her breasts, she lazily reached over and turned the water off.

She sat in complete silence for several minutes, enjoying the warm, the bubbles and her belly.

Then --

"URRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRP!!!"

She blushed with embarrassment, then shrugged since there had been no one to listen anyway. She laid her back against the pillow and enjoyed a nice long food coma.

A few hours later, when she woke up --

The Doctor, finally turning his head away from the TARDIS console he'd been observing so intently, looked upon his companion Amy Pond, still fussing over the wedding ring. Specifically it was her engagement ring, the only reminder in the universe of Rory Williams' existence. "Still obsessing over that ring?" the Doctor asked, trying to sound natural. Amy kept looking at it in wonder, practically not hearing the Doctor. After another 5 minutes of ring-staring, Amy went to her room, when the Doctor got a rather full observation of what Rory's erasure had done to poor Amy. 141.content:
From behind, only her long red hair would have given Amy away. Otherwise, her now wide hips and chunky lovehandles stretching her jeans and sweater to near ripping point made her complete unrecognizable from the front. The Doctor peered in on Amy, somewhat dreading the confrontation he was about to have. It wasn't so much that telling her she should lose weight would be awkward. The Doctor was fully aware this was frowned upon in many cultures. Mostly, it was that this weight gain was obviously just a symptom of her greater depression, and that he could do nothing about.

She was standing in front of an antique food dispenser in one of the TARDIS' many storage rooms. It had been from some alien encounter or other and the Doctor had accepted it as a gift, although never used it. Now Amy appeared so desperate for consolation she was searching the whole ship to new things to eat. The Doctor would have to hide this device later.

"Ah, Amy, how goes things on this fine day?" the Doctor said as unnaturally as he could.

Amy turned to him, her eyes already rolling, her puffier cheeks stuffed with an alien snack from the machine. It looked like a thick granola bar.

"What is it, Doctor?" she asked.

"Oh, nothing, just wondering how everything was?" he leaned as nonchalantly as he could on the machine, trying to not stare at how Amy's formerly figure-hiding sweater was now stretched around her swollen middle. "So, nice machine here, eh? Got this from the Vorgolon lobster people-"

"Doctor," Amy said, taking another bite, "Just tell me what you want to tell me."

"Very well," he toughened his voice a little, but tried not to sound too serious, "Pond, you've been putting on a lot of weight lately and, while I do understand it's from feeling depressed, I also understand it's not a healthy thing and you will probably regret if you continue to get all . . . " he motioned his hands in a vague circle, trying to come up with a word, ". . . blobby."

Amy's expression barely changed on her almost-but-not-quite-yet chubby face.

1413.content:
The Doctor braced for the impact his comment might have. No human woman would like being told she was getting fat, no matter how delicately and well intentioned the teller was.

Amy took another bite, chewing it slowly. She shook her head, her cheeks full, her eyes vacant, and her toned annoyed.

"What are you even talking about?"

She seemed to sincerely be unaware of the news that she was significantly heavier than she had been mere weeks, even days, before. The Doctor wobbled on his feet and began again.

"Well, it happens sometimes that even a woman of your, er, thinness, can be taken off guard by . . . changes like . . . this."

Amy released a tiny burp between chews, her expression growing both more confused and more frustrated. She tugged on her ever-tightening shirt. It used to be one of her larger sweaters, hiding her slim figure. Now it merely emphasized her lovehandles, and clung tightly across her softening stomach. The Doctor looked Amy up and down. Surely she wouldn't completely ignore the issue when brought up so gently.

"See, when you take in calories-"

She threw up a hand and shook her head, forcibly dismissing him.

"Not in the mood for these alien riddle mind games, Doctor." She walked past him. The Doctor, stunned, confused, but mostly curious, turned to watch her now soft ass as she brushed by. "When you have something-" much munch munch "-important to say then we'll talk."

"Huh."

Was Amy genuinely oblivious to her gain? Impossible, the Doctor thought. She was a pound away from ripping even the loosest of her clothes. For a girl as thin as she used to be surely she must notice how everything was getting bigger and softer, from her wide, wavering hips to her round, swollen belly to her equally puffy face. The poor girl must have put on twenty, thirty pounds at the least. Denial could be powerful, but that powerful?

Or, perhaps . . .

The Doctor aimed his sonic screwdriver at her. Perhaps there was something more than simple psychology and overeating at work here. It flashed and whirred, revealing--

Amy obliviously munched on an outrageously fattening health bar as she walked away from the Doctor. She wasn't at waddling size yet, although her hips were getting there even if her more ample ass and bloated belly were behind. Her aimed his sonic screwdriver at her and took some readings. They showed something, but not something he immediately recognized.

"Hold up, Amy," the Doctor said. Amy turned around, annoyance plastered all over her tired face as she swallowed.
